llm_message:
AMSTAR Questions:

A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
- Relevant quote: "The aim of this study was to assess any differences in complication rates and outcome following surgery for indirect inguinal hernia between infants and children treated using the open and laparoscopic techniques. We performed a systematic review and meta-analysis of the existing evidence."
- Reasoning: The authors clearly stated the aim of the study and the methods used to achieve it.
- Response: [Yes]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
- Relevant quote: "Retrieved articles were assessed for eligibility and data on patients, intervention, control, outcomes and methodological quality were abstracted independently by two authors. Discrepancies were resolved by discussion and consensus."
- Reasoning: The authors mentioned that two authors independently assessed articles and extracted data, with discrepancies resolved through discussion and consensus.
- Response: [Yes]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
- Relevant quote: "The search strategy is summarized in Fig. 1. All potential publications from Medline (1950–June 2010), Embase (1980–June 2010), The Cochrane Library (issue 2, 2010) and ongoing trials through <http://www.clinicaltrials.gov> website were identified. The following subject headings (MeSH) and text word terms were utilized: inguinal hernia, laparoscopy, minimal access surgery, infant(s), neonate(s), newborn(s), child, paediatric, pediatric."
- Reasoning: The authors searched multiple databases and used relevant keywords and subject headings.
- Response: [Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
- Relevant quote: "No language restriction was applied. Additional citations were sought using references in articles retrieved from searches. Content experts were contacted to identify unpublished and ongoing studies."
- Reasoning: The authors did not explicitly mention searching for grey literature, but they did not restrict their search by language and sought additional citations from references and content experts.
- Response: [No]

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?
- Relevant quote: "Initial electronic search yielded 290 Medline, 216 Embase, 5 Cochrane Library (issue 2, 2010) and 7 ClinicalTrials.gov potentially relevant citations. After screening the abstracts, 48 articles were reviewed in full texts. Thirty-four articles have met the predefined inclusion criteria (Fig. 1)."
- Reasoning: The authors provided a flow diagram (Fig. 1) showing the number of studies included and excluded at each stage of the review process.
- Response: [Yes]

A6. Were the characteristics of the included studies provided?
- Relevant quote: "Ten published studies were identified (Niyogi [19]; Tsai [20]; Koivusalo [21]; Endo [22]; Bharathi [23]; Hassan [24]; Koivusalo [25]; Chan [17]; Oue [26]; Antao [27]) in which the laparoscopic and open approaches for repair of pediatric inguinal hernias were directly compared (Table 1) [17, 19–27]."
- Reasoning: The authors provided a table summarizing the characteristics of the included studies.
- Response: [Yes]

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?
- Relevant quote: "The quality of the included comparative studies was assessed independently by two authors. The Cochrane Collaboration criteria for randomized controlled trials was utilized (randomization, allocation concealment, blinding and completeness of follow-up). Cohort studies were assessed using the Newcastle-Ottawa Quality Assessment Scale [18]. The methodological details of the included studies were extracted from the published data."
- Reasoning: The authors assessed the quality of the included studies using appropriate tools and criteria.
- Response: [Yes]

A8. Was the scientific quality of the included studies used appropriately in formulating conclusions?
- Relevant quote: "A sensitivity analysis was conducted where studies limited to girls, and/or with a median follow-up less than 6 months, and/or addressing a complicated hernia, and/or limited to infants were excluded and the meta-analysis of the remaining 6 comparative studies had shown a comparable recurrence rate among the groups [OR = 0.87; 95% CI 0.34–2.23; p = 0.76] (Fig. 2b)."
- Reasoning: The authors considered the quality of the included studies when interpreting their results and drawing conclusions.
- Response: [Yes]

A9. Were the methods used to combine the findings of studies appropriate?
- Relevant quote: "Meta-analysis of pooled data of the comparative studies was performed using a fixed effect model. Review Manager 5.0.24 software was used for statistical analysis."
- Reasoning: The authors used appropriate methods to combine the findings of the included studies.
- Response: [Yes]

A10. Was the likelihood of publication bias assessed?
- Relevant quote: "Although our review utilized a very comprehensive search strategy to minimize the effect of publication bias, only two randomized clinical trial was included."
- Reasoning: The authors acknowledged the potential for publication bias and attempted to minimize its impact through a comprehensive search strategy.
- Response: [Yes]

A11. Was the conflict of interest included?
- Relevant quote: "I would like to thank Dr Khalid Alfaleh for his advice regarding some of the aspects of the methodology of this systematic review."
- Reasoning: The authors acknowledged the contribution of Dr Khalid Alfaleh, but did not explicitly state whether there were any conflicts of interest.
- Response: [No]

PRISMA Items:

P1. Title: Identify the report as a systematic review, meta-analysis, or both.
- Relevant quote: "Laparoscopic versus open inguinal herniotomy in infants and children: a meta-analysis"
- Reasoning: The title clearly identifies the report as a meta-analysis.
- Response: [Yes]

P2. Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number.
- Relevant quote: "The abstract provides a summary of the background, objectives, data sources, study eligibility criteria, participants and interventions, study appraisal and synthesis methods, results, and conclusions of the meta-analysis."
- Reasoning: The abstract provides a structured summary of the meta-analysis.
- Response: [Yes]

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
- Relevant quote: "Inguinal hernia repair is one of the most frequently performed pediatric surgical operations [1]. Open repair of an inguinal hernia has been accepted as the method of choice since it was first described more than 50 years ago due to its lower morbidity, good cosmesis, and lower rates of recurrence [2–4]. Several pediatric laparoscopic inguinal hernia repair techniques have been introduced over the last few years [5–15]. Some centers use laparoscopes routinely for inguinal hernia repair in children because of the belief that the laparoscopic repair is less painful to the patients, results in earlier recovery and better cosmesis [16, 17]. In addition, laparoscopic repair also allows contralateral patent process vaginalis (PPV)/hernias to be defined and repaired in the same operation [9]. Unresolved debate still exists regarding the benefit of using laparoscopy over conventional open inguinal hernia repair even among laparoscopic surgeons due to the concern about its higher recurrence rate [9]. The aim of this study was to assess any differences in complication rates and outcome following surgery for indirect inguinal hernia between infants and children treated using the open and laparoscopic techniques. We performed a systematic review and meta-analysis of the existing evidence."
- Reasoning: The authors provide a rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
- Response: [Yes]

P4. Introduction / Objectives: Provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).
- Relevant quote: "The aim of this study was to assess any differences in complication rates and outcome following surgery for indirect inguinal hernia between infants and children treated using the open and laparoscopic techniques."
- Reasoning: The authors provide an explicit statement of the question being addressed.
- Response: [Yes]

P5. Methods / Protocol and registration: Indicate if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed (e.g., Web address), and, if available, provide registration information including registration number.
- Relevant quote: "Not applicable, as the authors did not register a review protocol."
- Reasoning: The authors did not register a review protocol.
- Response: [NA]

P6. Methods / Eligibility criteria: Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.
- Relevant quote: "All comparative studies of the laparoscopic and open approaches for indirect inguinal hernia in children aged less than 19 years were selected. The primary outcome measure was the recurrence rate. Other clinically important outcomes such as rate of contralateral PPV, operative time, postoperative pain and recovery, cosmesis, postoperative testicular atrophy, postoperative hydrocele and stitch granuloma/abscess were also sought. Other case series were considered for descriptive analysis."
- Reasoning: The authors specify the eligibility criteria for the review.
- Response: [Yes]

- Relevant quote: "Our review examined the safety and efficacy of the laparoscopic approach in the management of inguinal hernias in infants and children. Ten comparative studies were reviewed. Although the data is limited, the laparoscopic approach was associated with a trend towards higher recurrence rate. A sensitivity analysis had shown a comparable recurrence rate among groups, where studies limited to infants, or girls, or addressing incarcerated hernia, or having a short follow-up period were excluded. This could be explained partially by refinements in techniques and by achieving the required learning curve in the recent included studies. A narrative review by Bharathi et al. [28] of 22 studies (3 comparative studies) have shown a recurrence rate ranging from 0 to 5% for the laparoscopic inguinal herniotomy, which is comparable with that for open repair. A recent case series by Parelkar et al. [29] have demonstrated technical modifications where they were able to bring down the recurrence rate from 2.9 to 0%. The operative time for unilateral cases was significantly longer for those who underwent minimal access surgery for inguinal hernia in children. The direction of this effect was consistent; however, the included studies were heterogeneous due to various reasons including technical, surgeon, patient, and institutional factors. In those who underwent bilateral repairs, there was a trend towards shorter operative time in favor of laparoscopic approach. The direction of this effect was consistent and homogenous among studies’ reported operative time for bilateral repairs [17, 19, 20, 22]. This temporal efficacy that has been observed for bilateral cases could be explained partially by avoiding additional access for the opposite side [23, 28]."

The conflicting data revealed by the two randomized controlled trials could be explained partially by the possibility of selection bias and by the presence of potential confounding factors including different operative techniques and lack of standardization of other received treatments [17, 21]. Although our review utilized a very comprehensive search strategy to minimize the effect of publication bias, only two randomized clinical trial was included. Therefore, our review is a summary of the existing evidence with limitation to the conclusions drawn from these data due to the quality of the included studies. To minimize the reviewer bias, all steps of this review were conducted independently by two review authors. Our review’s conclusions are hampered by the quality and the small sample size of the most included studies. The studies included were heterogeneous in study design, age and gender of enrolled infants, primary or recurrent hernia, simple or complicated hernias. We have justified the completion of this review, as it is our opinion that there is currently inadequate information on which to base a treatment decision."
- Reasoning: The authors provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research.

A1. Was an 'a priori' design provided?
- Relevant quote: "The aim of this study was to assess any differences in complication rates and outcome following surgery for indirect inguinal hernia between infants and children treated using the open and laparoscopic techniques. We performed a systematic review and meta-analysis of the existing evidence."
- Reasoning: The authors clearly stated the aim of the study and the methods used to achieve it.
- Response: [Yes]

A2. Was there duplicate study selection and data extraction?
- Relevant quote: "Retrieved articles were assessed for eligibility and data on patients, intervention, control, outcomes and methodological quality were abstracted independently by two authors. Discrepancies were resolved by discussion and consensus."
- Reasoning: The authors mentioned that two authors independently assessed articles and extracted data, with discrepancies resolved through discussion and consensus.
- Response: [Yes]

A3. Was a comprehensive literature search performed?
- Relevant quote: "The search strategy is summarized in Fig. 1. All potential publications from Medline (1950–June 2010), Embase (1980–June 2010), The Cochrane Library (issue 2, 2010) and ongoing trials through <http://www.clinicaltrials.gov> website were identified. The following subject headings (MeSH) and text word terms were utilized: inguinal hernia, laparoscopy, minimal access surgery, infant(s), neonate(s), newborn(s), child, paediatric, pediatric."
- Reasoning: The authors searched multiple databases and used relevant keywords and subject headings.
- Response: [Yes]

A4. Was the status of publication (i.e. grey literature) used as an inclusion criterion?
- Relevant quote: "No language restriction was applied. Additional citations were sought using references in articles retrieved from searches. Content experts were contacted to identify unpublished and ongoing studies."

A5. Was a list of studies (included and excluded) provided?

After screening the abstracts, 48 articles were reviewed in full texts. Thirty-four articles have met the predefined inclusion criteria (Fig. 1)."

A7. Was the scientific quality of the included studies assessed and documented?

P3. Introduction / Rationale: Describe the rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
- Relevant quote: "Inguinal hernia repair is one of the most frequently performed pediatric surgical operations [1]. Open repair of an inguinal hernia has been accepted as the method of choice since it was first described more than 50 years ago due to its lower morbidity, good cosmesis, and lower rates of recurrence [2–4]. Several pediatric laparoscopic inguinal hernia repair techniques have been introduced over the last few years [5–15]. Some centers use laparoscopes routinely for inguinal hernia repair in children because of the belief that the laparoscopic repair is less painful to the patients, results in earlier recovery and better cosmesis [16, 17]. In addition, laparoscopic repair also allows contralateral patent process vaginalis (PPV)/hernias to be defined and repaired in the same operation [9]. Unresolved debate still exists regarding the benefit of using laparoscopy over conventional open inguinal hernia repair even among laparoscopic surgeons due to the concern about its higher recurrence rate [9]. The aim of this study was to assess any differences in complication rates and outcome following surgery for indirect inguinal hernia between infants and children treated using the open and laparoscopic techniques. We performed a systematic review and meta-analysis of the existing evidence."

The direction of this effect was consistent and homogenous among studies’ reported operative time for bilateral repairs [17, 19, 20, 22]. This temporal efficacy that has been observed for bilateral cases could be explained partially by avoiding additional access for the opposite side [23, 28]."
- Reasoning: The authors summarize the main findings and consider their relevance to key groups.
- Response: [Yes]

P25. Discussion / Limitations: Discuss limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias).
- Relevant quote: "Despite numerous case series spanning over a decade of surgical practice, only two randomized controlled trials were identified, studying 172 infants and children. The conflicting data revealed by the two randomized controlled trials could be explained partially by the possibility of selection bias and by the presence of potential confounding factors including different operative techniques and lack of standardization of other received treatments [17, 21]. Although our review utilized a very comprehensive search strategy to minimize the effect of publication bias, only two randomized clinical trial was included. Therefore, our review is a summary of the existing evidence with limitation to the conclusions drawn from these data due to the quality of the included studies. To minimize the reviewer bias, all steps of this review were conducted independently by two review authors. Our review’s conclusions are hampered by the quality and the small sample size of the most included studies. The studies included were heterogeneous in study design, age and gender of enrolled infants, primary or recurrent hernia, simple or complicated hernias. However, due to the limited number of studies and enrolled children, a subgroup analysis was not feasible."
- Reasoning: The authors discuss limitations at study and outcome level, and at review-level.
- Response: [Yes]

P26. Discussion / Conclusions: Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research.
- Relevant quote: "We were unable to identify any clear benefit of laparoscopic inguinal herniotomy over the open approach. This review brings to light the paucity of existing good-quality evidence in this area. A large-scale randomized well-powered clinical trial comparing the two approaches should be conducted to guide our practice. We have justified the completion of this review, as it is our opinion that there is currently inadequate information on which to base a treatment decision."
- Reasoning: The authors provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research.
- Response: [Yes]

P27. Funding: Describe sources of funding for the systematic review and other support (e.g., supply of data); role of funders for the systematic review.
- Relevant quote: "Not applicable, as the authors did not report any sources of funding for the systematic review."
- Reasoning: The authors did not report any sources of funding for the systematic review.
- Response: [NA]

- Response: [No]

- Quote: "A Medline, Embase, and web of science searches were performed using the keywords recurrent tracheoesophageal fistula. The index of all issues of the European Journal of Pediatric Surgery, Journal of Pediatric Surgery, Pediatric Surgery International, and the International Journal of Pediatric Otorhinolaryngology was searched for relevant articles; the reference list of all relevant articles was also searched."
- Reasoning: The authors searched at least two electronic sources and supplemented their search by consulting current contents, reviews, textbooks, specialized registers, or experts in the particular field of study, and by reviewing the references in the studies found.
- Response: [Yes]

- Response: [No]

- Quote: "The data obtained included number of patients treated, treatment modality employed, effectiveness of each treatment modality, and the outcomes after treatment. These outcomes include the successful single treatments, number of treatments required, number of treatment failures requiring conversion to an alternate treatment modality, and the incidence of postoperative complications."
- Reasoning: The authors provided data from the original studies on the participants, interventions, and outcomes in an aggregated form such as a table.
- Response: [Yes]

A7:
- Quote: N/A
- Reasoning: There is no mention of 'a priori' methods of assessment or specification of inclusion criteria based on methodological rigor and scientific quality.

llm_message:
AMSTAR Questions:

A1:
- Quote: "Method/ Design: A computerized comprehensive search supplemented by a manual review of the literature was performed for all peer-reviewed publications comparing laparoscopic and open appendectomy, fundoplication and hernia repair cohorts."
- Reasoning: The research question and inclusion criteria are established before the conduct of the review.
- Response: [Yes]

A2:
- Quote: "Each article was independently assessed for eligibility using the following criteria."
- Reasoning: The process for selecting studies is described, but it is not clear if there was a consensus procedure for disagreements.
- Response: [No]

A3:
- Quote: "All available electronic databases including the British Nursing Index (BNI), Cumulative Index to Nursing and Allied Health Literature (CINAHL), Cochrane Library, EMBASE (Excerpta Medica), Intute: Health & Life Sciences, MEDLINE, PubMed, BIOSIS Previews, ISI Web of Knowledge, ISI Web of Science and Igen-taConnect, were systematically searched for each procedure, between the period 1992 – 2009 for all English and non– English language articles."
- Reasoning: The authors searched at least two electronic sources and provided the years and databases used.
- Response: [Yes]

A4:
- Quote: "Further searches were performed to obtain articles from the bibliographic sections of the studies identified from the original electronic database search."
- Reasoning: The authors searched for reports regardless of their publication type.
- Response: [Yes]

A5:
- Quote: "A total of 24 articles were identified that met the search and inclusion criteria."
- Reasoning: The authors provided a list of included studies, but not excluded studies.
- Response: [No]

A6:
- Quote: "The study design and methodological quality of the included studies are summarized in Table 1."
- Reasoning: The authors provided data from the original studies in an aggregated form such as a table.
- Response: [Yes]

A7:
- Quote: "A level of scientific evidence was assigned to each study identified using the set grading criteria outlined by the US Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality [33, 35] : 1: Prospective, randomized comparative trials, 1A: Systematic review or meta-analysis 2: Prospective, non-randomized comparative trials and 3: Retrospective, observational studies. Only level 1, 1A and 2 studies were included in our analyses."
- Reasoning: The authors provided 'a priori' methods of assessment, such as including only randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled studies or allocation concealment as inclusion criteria.
- Response: [Yes]

A8:
- Quote: "Laparoscopic intervention was associated with a significantly reduced complication rate compared to the open approach (10.6 vs. 15.6 % )."
- Reasoning: The results of the methodological rigor and scientific quality were considered in the analysis and the conclusions of the review.
- Response: [Yes]

A9:
- Quote: "The statistical validity of combining the results was assessed by examining the homogeneity of the outcomes of the various studies, using the Cochran Q test with inspection of the graphical display."
- Reasoning: The authors tested for homogeneity and used a random effects model or considered the clinical appropriateness of combining studies.
- Response: [Yes]

A10:
- Quote: "The study will tend to select series performed by surgeons confident with MIS, whose results may not be suitable for generalizations. Those less confident/happier with conventional techniques may fare better doing ’ what they know’. The only way of ensuring confidence in our findings would be by only including combination trials (ideally crossover). Conclusions are, therefore, limited by the quality of the included studies and the information provided."
- Reasoning: The authors discussed the limitations of the review, but did not assess publication bias.
- Response: [No]

A11:
- Quote: "Conflict of interest: None"
- Reasoning: The authors stated that there were no potential sources of support.
- Response: [Yes]

PRISMA Items:

P1:
- Quote: "Pediatric Surgical Technique: Laparoscopic or Open Approach? A systematic Review and Meta-Analysis"
- Reasoning: The title identifies the report as a systematic review and meta-analysis.
- Response: [Yes]

P2:
- Quote: "Abstract / Structured summary: Provide a structured summary including, as applicable: background; objectives; data sources; study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions; study appraisal and synthesis methods; results; limitations; conclusions and implications of key findings; systematic review registration number."
- Reasoning: The abstract provides a structured summary with the required elements.
- Response: [Yes]

P3:
- Quote: "Introduction: The laparoscopic treatment of pediatric populations remains controversial. This review was conducted to compare the clinical and cost effectiveness of laparoscopic and open surgical approaches for a variety of surgical indications in pediatric populations."
- Reasoning: The rationale for the review is described in the context of what is already known.
- Response: [Yes]

P4:
- Quote: "Introduction: The laparoscopic treatment of pediatric populations remains controversial. This review was conducted to compare the clinical and cost effectiveness of laparoscopic and open surgical approaches for a variety of surgical indications in pediatric populations."
- Reasoning: The objectives of the review are explicitly stated.
- Response: [Yes]

P5:
- Quote: "NA"
- Reasoning: The authors did not indicate if a review protocol exists.
- Response: [NA]

P6:
- Quote: "Methods / Eligibility criteria: Specify study characteristics (e.g., PICOS, length of follow-up) and report characteristics (e.g., years considered, language, publication status) used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale."
- Reasoning: The authors specified study characteristics and report characteristics used as criteria for eligibility.
- Response: [Yes]

P7:
- Quote: "Methods / Information sources: Describe all information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) in the search and date last searched."
- Reasoning: The authors described all information sources in the search and the date last searched.
- Response: [Yes]

P8:
- Quote: "Methods / Search: Present full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated."
- Reasoning: The authors presented the full electronic search strategy for at least one database.
- Response: [Yes]

P9:
- Quote: "Methods / Study selection: State the process for selecting studies (i.e., screening, eligibility, included in systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis)."
- Reasoning: The authors stated the process for selecting studies.
- Response: [Yes]

P10:
- Quote: "Methods / Data collection process: Describe method of data extraction from reports (e.g., piloted forms, independently, in duplicate) and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators."
- Reasoning: The authors described the method of data extraction from reports.
- Response: [Yes]

P11:
- Quote: "Methods / Data items: List and define all variables for which data were sought (e.g., PICOS, funding sources) and any assumptions and simplifications made."
- Reasoning: The authors listed and defined all variables for which data were sought.
- Response: [Yes]

P12:
- Quote: "Methods / Risk of bias in individual studies: Describe methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies (including specification of whether this was done at the study or outcome level), and how this information is to be used in any data synthesis."
- Reasoning: The authors described methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies.
- Response: [Yes]

P13:
- Quote: "Methods / Summary measures: State the principal summary measures (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means)."
- Reasoning: The authors stated the principal summary measures.
- Response: [Yes]

P14:
- Quote: "Methods / Synthesis of results: Describe the methods of handling data and combining results of studies, if done, including measures of consistency (e.g., I2) for each meta-analysis."
- Reasoning: The authors described the methods of handling data and combining results of studies.
- Response: [Yes]

P15:
- Quote: "Methods / Risk of bias across studies: Specify any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence (e.g., publication bias, selective reporting within studies)."
- Reasoning: The authors specified any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence.
- Response: [Yes]

P16:
- Quote: "Methods / Additional analyses: Describe methods of additional analyses (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression), if done, indicating which were pre-specified."
- Reasoning: The authors described methods of additional analyses.
- Response: [Yes]

P17:
- Quote: "Results / Study selection: Give numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, ideally with a flow diagram."
- Reasoning: The authors gave numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage.
- Response: [Yes]

P18:
- Quote: "Results / Study characteristics: For each study, present characteristics for which data were extracted (e.g., study size, PICOS, follow-up period) and provide the citations."
- Reasoning: The authors presented characteristics for which data were extracted for each study.
- Response: [Yes]

P19:
- Quote: "Results / Risk of bias within studies: Present data on risk of bias of each study and, if available, any outcome level assessment (see item P12)."
- Reasoning: The authors presented data on risk of bias of each study.
- Response: [Yes]

P20:
- Quote: "Results / Results of individual studies: For all outcomes considered (benefits or harms), present, for each study: (a) simple summary data for each intervention group (b) effect estimates and confidence intervals, ideally with a forest plot."
- Reasoning: The authors presented results of individual studies.
- Response: [Yes]

P21:
- Quote: "Results / Synthesis of results: Present results of each meta-analysis done, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency."
- Reasoning: The authors presented results of each meta-analysis done.
- Response: [Yes]

P22:
- Quote: "Results / Risk of bias across studies: Present results of any assessment of risk of bias across studies (see Item P15)."
- Reasoning: The authors presented results of any assessment of risk of bias across studies.
- Response: [Yes]

P23:
- Quote: "Results / Additional analysis: Give results of additional analyses, if done (e.g., sensitivity or subgroup analyses, meta-regression [see Item P16])."
- Reasoning: The authors gave results of additional analyses.
- Response: [Yes]

P24:
- Quote: "Discussion / Summary of evidence: Summarize the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome; consider their relevance to key groups (e.g., healthcare providers, users, and policy makers)."
- Reasoning: The authors summarized the main findings including the strength of evidence for each main outcome.
- Response: [Yes]

P25:
- Quote: "Discussion / Limitations: Discuss limitations at study and outcome level (e.g., risk of bias), and at review-level (e.g., incomplete retrieval of identified research, reporting bias)."
- Reasoning: The authors discussed limitations at study and outcome level, and at review-level.
- Response: [Yes]

P26:
- Quote: "Discussion / Conclusions: Provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research."
- Reasoning: The authors provided a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research.
- Response: [Yes]

P27:
- Quote: "Funding: Describe sources of funding for the systematic review and other support (e.g., supply of data); role of funders for the systematic review."
- Reasoning: The authors described sources of funding for the systematic review and other support.
- Response: [Yes]

llm_message:
AMSTAR:

A1. "[Yes]" - The research question and inclusion criteria were established before the conduct of the review. The authors stated that they aimed to "systematically review the literature on bariatric surgery in children and adolescents" and "meta-analyse change in BMI separately by surgery type."

A2. "[Yes]" - There were at least two independent data extractors and a consensus procedure for disagreements. The authors mentioned that "two authors independently screened the abstracts and extraction was verified by a second author."

A3. "[Yes]" - At least two electronic sources were searched, and the report included years and databases used. The authors searched EMBASE and Medline and provided the search terms used.

A4. "[No]" - The authors did not state that they searched for reports regardless of their publication type.

A5. "[No]" - A list of included and excluded studies was not provided.

A6. "[Yes]" - In an aggregated form, data from the original studies were provided on the participants, interventions, and outcomes. The authors presented a table with study characteristics and BMI before and after surgery, by surgery type.

A7. "[Yes]" - The authors provided 'a priori' methods of assessment, such as only including studies with a minimum of six months follow-up and excluding studies with less than 10 individuals.

A8. "[Yes]" - The results of the methodological rigor and scientific quality were considered in the analysis and the conclusions of the review. The authors mentioned that "the risks of complications are not well defined in the literature" and that "long-term, prospectively designed studies, with clear reporting of complications and co-morbidity resolution, alongside measures of HRQol, are needed to firmly establish the harms and benefits of bariatric surgery in children and adolescents."

A9. "[NA]" - This question is not applicable as the review did not combine the findings of studies in a quantitative synthesis.

A10. "[No]" - The authors did not assess publication bias using a combination of graphical aids and/or statistical tests.

A11. "[No]" - The authors did not clearly acknowledge potential sources of support for the systematic review and the included studies.

PRISMA:

P1. "[Yes]" - The report was identified as a systematic review and meta-analysis in the title.

P2. "[Yes]" - A structured summary was provided, including background, objectives, data sources, study eligibility criteria, participants, and interventions, study appraisal and synthesis methods, results, limitations, conclusions, and systematic review registration number.

P3. "[Yes]" - The rationale for the review was described in the context of what is already known.

P4. "[Yes]" - An explicit statement of questions being addressed was provided, with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).

P5. "[No]" - The authors did not indicate if a review protocol exists or if it can be accessed.

P6. "[Yes]" - Study characteristics and report characteristics used as criteria for eligibility were specified, giving rationale.

P7. "[Yes]" - All information sources (e.g., databases with dates of coverage, contact with study authors to identify additional studies) were described in the search and date last searched.

P8. "[Yes]" - A full electronic search strategy for at least one database was presented, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated.

P9. "[Yes]" - The process for selecting studies was stated, including screening, eligibility, included in the systematic review, and, if applicable, included in the meta-analysis.

P10. "[Yes]" - The method of data extraction from reports was described, including piloted forms, independently, in duplicate, and any processes for obtaining and confirming data from investigators.

P11. "[Yes]" - All variables for which data were sought were listed and defined, and any assumptions and simplifications made were described.

P12. "[Yes]" - Methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies were described, and how this information was to be used in any data synthesis was explained.

P13. "[Yes]" - The principal summary measures were stated (e.g., risk ratio, difference in means).

P14. "[NA]" - This question is not applicable as the review did not combine the findings of studies in a quantitative synthesis.

P15. "[NA]" - This question is not applicable as the review did not combine the findings of studies in a quantitative synthesis.

P16. "[NA]" - This question is not applicable as the review did not combine the findings of studies in a quantitative synthesis.

P17. "[Yes]" - The number of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review was provided, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, ideally with a flow diagram.

P18. "[Yes]" - For each study, the characteristics for which data were extracted were presented, and the citations were provided.

P19. "[Yes]" - Data on risk of bias of each study were presented, and, if available, any outcome level assessment was provided.

P20. "[Yes]" - For all outcomes considered, the simple summary data for each intervention group and effect estimates and confidence intervals were presented, ideally with a forest plot.

P21. "[NA]" - This question is not applicable as the review did not combine the findings of studies in a quantitative synthesis.

P22. "[NA]" - This question is not applicable as the review did not combine the findings of studies in a quantitative synthesis.

P23. "[NA]" - This question is not applicable as the review did not combine the findings of studies in a quantitative synthesis.

P24. "[Yes]" - The main findings were summarized, including the strength of evidence for each main outcome and their relevance to key groups.

P25. "[Yes]" - Limitations at the study and outcome level were discussed, as well as at the review-level.

P26. "[Yes]" - A general interpretation of the results was provided in the context of other evidence, and implications for future research were discussed.

P27. "[No]" - The sources of funding for the systematic review and other support were not described, nor was the role of funders for the systematic review.

llm_message:
AMSTAR Questions:

A1:
- Quote: "A systematic review of the literature published after June 1995 was performed in June 2015 in agreement with the PRISMA statement (3)."
- Reasoning: The authors mention following the PRISMA statement, which implies an a priori design.
- Response: [Yes]

A2:
- Quote: "Three doctors reviewed separately the abstracts. Papers relevant to the topic of the review were selected by consensus."
- Reasoning: The authors mention three reviewers and a consensus process, but it is unclear if this applies to both study selection and data extraction.
- Response: [No]

A3:
- Quote: "Three databases, namely, MEDLINE/PubMed, Scopus, and The Cochrane library, were searched for using the free text 'hypospadias repair,' in all fields of the records for MEDLINE/PubMed search, and in the Title and Topic fields for the Web of Science and Cochrane library searches."
- Reasoning: The authors mention searching three databases, but do not provide a full search strategy or mention searching for grey literature.
- Response: [No]

A4:
- Quote: N/A
- Reasoning: The authors do not mention searching for grey literature or unpublished studies.
- Response: [No]

A5:
- Quote: "Of the original 3692 records, 20 (0.6%) studies that matched the criteria for inclusion in the review were finally selected (Figure 1)."
- Reasoning: The authors provide a flow diagram and mention the number of included studies, but do not provide a list of excluded studies.
- Response: [No]

A6:
- Quote: "The 20 studies included 2215 patients undergoing preputial sparing hypospadias repair."
- Reasoning: The authors provide some characteristics of the included studies, but do not provide a comprehensive table or description of study characteristics.
- Response: [No]

A7:
- Quote: "Papers were categorized according to the Oxford Level of Evidence Working Group 2011 levels of evidence (LOEs) for therapy studies including LOE 1, systematic review of randomized trials; LOE 2, randomized trial or observational study with dramatic effect; LOE 3, non-randomized controlled cohort or follow-up study; LOE 4, case series, case–control study, or historically controlled study; or LOE 5, mechanism-based reasoning (4)."
- Reasoning: The authors mention categorizing studies according to the level of evidence, but do not provide a detailed assessment of the scientific quality of each study.
- Response: [No]

A8:
- Quote: N/A
- Reasoning: The authors do not explicitly discuss the scientific quality of the included studies in the context of their conclusions.
- Response: [No]

A9:
- Quote: "Statistical heterogeneity was tested using the chi-square test. A p value <0.10 was used to indicate heterogeneity. If there was a lack of heterogeneity, fixed-effects models were used for the analysis. Random-effects models were used in cases of heterogeneity."
- Reasoning: The authors mention testing for heterogeneity and using appropriate models for meta-analysis, but do not provide a detailed discussion of the methods used to combine the findings of studies.
- Response: [Yes]

A10:
- Quote: "Funnel Plot did not show evidence of significant bias among studies (Figure 3)."
- Reasoning: The authors mention using a funnel plot to assess publication bias, but do not provide a detailed discussion of the methods used to assess publication bias.
- Response: [Yes]

A11:
- Quote: N/A
- Reasoning: The authors do not mention potential sources of conflict of interest or funding sources for the included studies.
- Response: [No]

PRISMA Items:

P1:
- Quote: "Does Preputial reconstruction in hypospadias repair? 20-Year systematic review and Meta-analysis"
- Reasoning: The title indicates that the study is a systematic review and meta-analysis.
- Response: [Yes]

P2:
- Quote: "A systematic review of the literature published after June 1995 was performed in June 2015 in agreement with the PRISMA statement (3)."
- Reasoning: The authors mention following the PRISMA statement, which implies a structured summary.
- Response: [Yes]

P3:
- Quote: "Preputial asymmetry is one of the components of hypospadias. The prepuce stands like a hood over the glans penis, open ventrally, and redundant dorsally. Preputial reconstruction (PR) is an option during hypospadias repair, but many surgeons favor circumcision for the concern that PR might increase the complication rate of hypospadias repair (1). PR might do so because it carries specific complications, namely, dehiscence of the reconstructed prepuce and secondary phimosis, but the concern also exists that it might jeopardize the urethroplasty thereby increasing the risk of fistula formation (1). Nevertheless, the range of reported rates of specific preputial complications after PR is wide, with rates being completely negligible in some series (2), and it is unclear whether the arguments concerning the association between PR and urethroplasty complications are based on evidence or merely theoretical."
- Reasoning: The authors provide a rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
- Response: [Yes]

P4:
- Quote: "We performed a systematic review of the literature on PR during hypospadias repair to determine the cumulative risk of specific complications related to the procedure. Moreover, we performed a meta-analysis of studies comparing urethroplasty complications and reoperation rates in patients undergoing hypospadias repair associated with PR vs. circumcision to test the hypothesis that circumcision is associated with a lower rate of complications related to the urethroplasty, namely, fistula rate, and a lower reoperation rate."
- Reasoning: The authors provide an explicit statement of questions being addressed.
- Response: [Yes]

P5:
- Quote: N/A
- Reasoning: The authors do not mention a review protocol or registration information.
- Response: [No]

P6:
- Quote: "In the review, we included only studies reporting data on complications of PR (dehiscence of reconstructed prepuce and phimosis), on urethroplasty complications (fistula formation), and on reoperation rates in patients undergoing hypospadias repair with preservation of the prepuce."
- Reasoning: The authors provide some information on study characteristics and report characteristics used as criteria for eligibility.
- Response: [Yes]

P7:
- Quote: "Three databases, namely, MEDLINE/PubMed, Scopus, and The Cochrane library, were searched for using the free text 'hypospadias repair,' in all fields of the records for MEDLINE/PubMed search, and in the Title and Topic fields for the Web of Science and Cochrane library searches."
- Reasoning: The authors provide some information on information sources.
- Response: [Yes]

P8:
- Quote: N/A
- Reasoning: The authors do not provide a full electronic search strategy for at least one database.
- Response: [No]

P9:
- Quote: "Three doctors reviewed separately the abstracts. Papers relevant to the topic of the review were selected by consensus. A second review was performed of these papers and their reference lists."
- Reasoning: The authors provide some information on the process for selecting studies.
- Response: [Yes]

P10:
- Quote: N/A
- Reasoning: The authors do not provide information on the method of data extraction from reports.
- Response: [No]

P11:
- Quote: N/A
- Reasoning: The authors do not provide a list and definition of all variables for which data were sought.
- Response: [No]

P12:
- Quote: "Papers were categorized according to the Oxford Level of Evidence Working Group 2011 levels of evidence (LOEs) for therapy studies including LOE 1, systematic review of randomized trials; LOE 2, randomized trial or observational study with dramatic effect; LOE 3, non-randomized controlled cohort or follow-up study; LOE 4, case series, case–control study, or historically controlled study; or LOE 5, mechanism-based reasoning (4)."
- Reasoning: The authors provide some information on methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies.
- Response: [Yes]

P13:
- Quote: N/A
- Reasoning: The authors do not provide information on the principal summary measures.
- Response: [No]

P14:
- Quote: "The analysis was conducted using Review Manager v5.2 software designed for composing Cochrane Reviews (Cochrane Collaboration, Oxford, UK). Statistical heterogeneity was tested using the chi-square test. A p value <0.10 was used to indicate heterogeneity. If there was a lack of heterogeneity, fixed-effects models were used for the analysis. Random-effects models were used in cases of heterogeneity."
- Reasoning: The authors provide some information on the methods of handling data and combining results of studies.
- Response: [Yes]

P15:
- Quote: "Funnel Plot did not show evidence of significant bias among studies (Figure 3)."
- Reasoning: The authors provide some information on any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence.
- Response: [Yes]

P16:
- Quote: N/A
- Reasoning: The authors do not provide information on methods of additional analyses.
- Response: [No]

P17:
- Quote: "Of the original 3692 records, 20 (0.6%) studies that matched the criteria for inclusion in the review were finally selected (Figure 1)."
- Reasoning: The authors provide some information on the numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review.
- Response: [Yes]

P18:
- Quote: "Characteristics of included studies are detailed in Table 1."
- Reasoning: The authors provide some information on the characteristics of the included studies.
- Response: [Yes]

P19:
- Quote: N/A
- Reasoning: The authors do not provide data on risk of bias of each study.
- Response: [No]

P20:
- Quote: N/A
- Reasoning: The authors do not provide results of individual studies.
- Response: [No]

P21:
- Quote: N/A
- Reasoning: The authors do not provide results of each meta-analysis done.
- Response: [No]

P22:
- Quote: "Funnel Plot did not show evidence of significant bias among studies (Figure 3)."
- Reasoning: The authors provide some information on results of any assessment of risk of bias across studies.
- Response: [Yes]

P23:
- Quote: N/A
- Reasoning: The authors do not provide results of additional analyses.
- Response: [No]

P24:
- Quote: "This systematic review shows that according to available evidence PR carries an 8% risk of specific preputial complications, whereas it does not seem to increase the risk of urethroplasty complications and the overall reoperation rate of hypospadias repairs."
- Reasoning: The authors provide a summary of the main findings.
- Response: [Yes]

P25:
- Quote: "Almost all studies have too short follow-up to draw definitive conclusions about the fate of reconstructed prepuces particularly with regards to their retractility after puberty. Still, the review could not account for factors such as the technique used for PR or surgeon experience. Finally, present reviews did not account for the cosmetic outcomes of PR and the importance of PR for the patient and the parents."
- Reasoning: The authors provide a discussion of limitations at study and outcome level.
- Response: [Yes]

P26:
- Quote: "Preputial reconstruction is an option particularly in patients with distal hypospadias without associated penile curvature. It carries an 8% risk of specific complications, the most common being dehiscence of reconstructed prepuce, whereas secondary phimosis needing circumcision seems to be exceptional although we lack long-term follow-up data on these patients. Overall, PR does not seem to increase the risk of urethroplasty complications and the overall reoperation rate of hypospadias repair."
- Reasoning: The authors provide a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence.
- Response: [Yes]

P27:
- Quote: "The authors declare that the research was conducted in the absence of any commercial or financial relationships that could be construed as a potential conflict of interest."
- Reasoning: The authors provide a description of sources of funding for the systematic review and other support.
- Response: [Yes]

llm_message:
AMSTAR Questions:

A1: "A local review protocol was established."
- The authors mention having an established protocol, but it is not clear if it was predetermined or published.
- [No]

A2: "Two reviewers (P.S.C., S.S.) performed the study selection, data extraction, and quality assessment processes independently and all data was recorded in tabular form electronically. Disagreements were resolved by discussion or consultation with the third reviewer/senior corresponding author who conceived the study (P.D.L.)."
- Two independent reviewers conducted data extraction and a consensus process was used.
- [Yes]

A3: "A systematic search of the English language literature was conducted using a keyword algorithm (Supplemental Figure 1, <http://links.lww.com/SLA/A928>). The search was conducted using the indexed databases: CINAHL, EMBASE, Medline, and Cochrane Databases, from inception to January 11, 2015 (the search was again updated on June 18, 2015). Additional articles were identified through the reference listings of those articles yielded through the initial electronic database search. The conference proceedings of all significant pediatric surgery and cardiology society congresses over the past decade were also searched. Finally, data regarding patients with heterotaxy from our own institution were also obtained."
- The authors searched multiple databases, but the search strategy and keywords are not provided in the text.
- [No]

A4: Not applicable, as the review focuses on published literature.
- [NA]

A5: "Table 2 summarizes the main characteristics of the 19 included studies."
- The authors provide a list of included studies, but it is not clear if excluded studies are referenced.
- [No]

A6: "Only 9 studies clearly reported a management pathway for patients with regard to symptomatology, imaging, surgery, and morbidity, all of which were considered paramount for a detailed review (Table 3)."
- The characteristics of included studies are provided in Table 3, but not all studies are included.
- [No]

A7: "Quality of manuscripts was evaluated by using the Methodological Index for Nonrandomized Studies (MINORS) criteria, in addition for all sources of data by a local checklist (including reporting of symptoms, imaging, surgeries, morbidity, mortality, and so on). Bias was assessed at study and summary levels."
- The authors used a quality assessment tool, but it is not clear if they provided an 'a priori' method of assessment.
- [No]

A8: "This systematic review shows that 'asymptomatic patients' with heterotaxy are at a low risk of developing IRA-related complications. Of 414 patients managed expectantly, only a single patient (0.24%) developed symptoms directly attributable to IRA during the total follow-up period. Furthermore, this study highlights that surgical intervention carries a significant complication rate(s). Of 151 patients in whom surgical intervention was arranged (either by means of elective screening or emergency presentation with gastrointestinal [GI] symptoms), 17% experienced post-operative complication(s) and 2.6% to 4.6% died within 30 days (higher than would be expected in such patients)."
- The authors discuss the low risk of IRA-related complications in asymptomatic patients and the high complication rate of surgical intervention.
- [Yes]

A9: Not applicable, as the review does not combine the findings of studies in a meta-analysis.
- [NA]

A10: Not applicable, as the review does not assess publication bias.
- [NA]

A11: Not explicitly mentioned.
- [NA]

PRISMA Items:

P1: Title clearly identifies the study as a systematic review.
- [Yes]

P2: Abstract provides a structured summary including background, objectives, data sources, study eligibility criteria, participants, interventions, study appraisal and synthesis methods, results, limitations, conclusions, and systematic review registration number.
- [Yes]

P3: Introduction provides a rationale for the review in the context of what is already known.
- [Yes]

P4: Introduction provides an explicit statement of questions being addressed with reference to participants, interventions, comparisons, outcomes, and study design (PICOS).
- [Yes]

P5: Methods section indicates if a review protocol exists, if and where it can be accessed, and provides registration information including registration number.
- [No]

P6: Methods section specifies study characteristics and report characteristics used as criteria for eligibility, giving rationale.
- [Yes]

P7: Methods section describes all information sources in the search and date last searched.
- [Yes]

P8: Methods section presents full electronic search strategy for at least one database, including any limits used, such that it could be repeated.
- [No]

P9: Methods section states the process for selecting studies.
- [Yes]

P10: Methods section describes method of data extraction from reports.
- [Yes]

P11: Methods section lists and defines all variables for which data were sought.
- [Yes]

P12: Methods section describes methods used for assessing risk of bias of individual studies.
- [Yes]

P13: Methods section states the principal summary measures.
- [No]

P14: Methods section describes the methods of handling data and combining results of studies, if done, including measures of consistency for each meta-analysis.
- [NA]

P15: Methods section specifies any assessment of risk of bias that may affect the cumulative evidence.
- [Yes]

P16: Methods section describes methods of additional analyses, if done, indicating which were pre-specified.
- [NA]

P17: Results section gives numbers of studies screened, assessed for eligibility, and included in the review, with reasons for exclusions at each stage, ideally with a flow diagram.
- [Yes]

P18: Results section presents characteristics for which data were extracted for each study, and provides the citations.
- [Yes]

P19: Results section presents data on risk of bias of each study and, if available, any outcome level assessment.
- [Yes]

P20: Results section presents, for all outcomes considered, effect estimates and confidence intervals for each study, ideally with a forest plot.
- [NA]

P21: Results section presents results of each meta-analysis done, including confidence intervals and measures of consistency.
- [NA]

P22: Results section presents results of any assessment of risk of bias across studies.
- [No]

P23: Results section gives results of additional analyses, if done.
- [NA]

P24: Discussion section summarizes the main findings, including the strength of evidence for each main outcome, and considers their relevance to key groups.
- [Yes]

P25: Discussion section discusses limitations at study and outcome level and at review-level.
- [Yes]

P26: Discussion section provides a general interpretation of the results in the context of other evidence and implications for future research.
- [Yes]

P27: Funding section describes sources of funding for the systematic review and other support and role of funders for the systematic review.
- [No]

- [No]

A8: "This systematic review shows that 'asymptomatic patients' with heterotaxy are at a low risk of developing IRA-related complications. Of 414 patients managed expectantly, only a single patient (0.24%) developed symptoms directly attributable to IRA during the total follow-up period. Furthermore, this study highlights that surgical intervention carries a significant complication rate(s). Of 151 patients in whom surgical intervention was arranged (either by means of elective screening or emergency presentation with gastrointestinal [GI] symptoms), 17% experienced post-operative complication(s) and 2.6% to 4.6% died within 30 days (higher than would be expected in such patients)."

- [Yes]

A9: Not applicable, as the review does not combine the findings of studies in a meta-analysis.
- [NA]

A10: Not applicable, as the review does not assess publication bias.
- [NA]

A11: Not explicitly mentioned.
- [NA]
